doc.field: Chancellor Schroeder: realising Kosovo peace-plan should not take long

Chancellor Schroeder thinks that a quick realisation of the Kosovo peace-plan is possible. When interviewed on TV ZDF, he said that an agreement on the Kosovo security resolution could happen as early as this Sunday, when the G8 Foreign Ministers are going to meet in Bonn. UN General Secretary Annan said in New York that the Security Council would look into the resolution at the beginning of next week. He asked his special envoys Bildt and Kukan to set up a conference in Geneva, to wrap up the Kosovo crisis.

Following the backing of the Kosovo peace-resolution by the Yugoslavian government, NATO will take first steps to it realisation as early as Saturday. NATO-general Jackson will meet Yugoslavian generals at the Kosovo border. They will talk about the nitty-gritty of troop-withdrawals, which according to the resolution have to be finished within seven days. Germany supposedly will send more armed forces to join the planned Kosovo peace-corps than originally planned. According to secretary Wichert, there could be some 1000 additional soldiers.
No more air-raids on Serbian metropolitan centres

NATO stopped air-raids on Belgrade and Serbian metropolitan centres; they had not been targets for Friday night's sorties, according to NATO sources. Attacks against Serbian troops, however, had not slowed down. And apart from that, a headquarter of the special police and an airport had been bombed. France's head of state Chirac declared that from now on NATO would confine air-raids to military targets. Meanwhile the Kosovo Liberation Army (KLA) declared that Serbian armed forces had started a new offensive in the Kosovo.
Chancellor Schroeder: Agreement on Balkans can be finalised in June

Chancellor Schroeder thinks that the planned stability agreement for the Balkans could be finalised and signed in June. At the end of the EU-summit meeting in Cologne, Mr Schroeder said that the agreement, initiated by Germany, should provide long-term stability to the region. The states in the region, the EU, the US and Russia as well as international organisations should join. The agreement provides for aid to the Balkans and closer ties with the EU.
No more duty-free shopping within the EU at the end of this month

As planned, duty-free shopping within the EU will cease at the end of this month. During the EU-summit meeting, a majority had been for an extension of the current system, but this was vetoed by the Netherlands and Denmark. The heads of state also agreed on a resolution to reduce unemployment. Main issues of the agreement are co-ordination of economic policies and a joint strategy to improve labour markets and the base for innovation.
